Complex numbers possibly incorrect

note.body:
Speaking as a mathematician, actually both the answers for sqrt(-1) and sqrt(-2) are equally correct and equally incorrect.  From a pure mathematical standpoint, both are incorrect, as we never speak of *the* square root of anything other than a nonnegative real number.

In point of fact every complex number, including every real number, has *two* square roots: the square roots of 4 are 2 and -2, the square roots of -4 are 2i and -2i, the square roots of 2i are i+1 and -i-1, and so on.  In the case of a nonnegative real number, we can single out one of these roots as "preferred" over the other and call it "the" square root, namely the one that is also nonnegative.  That's the meaning of the √ sign: when we write √x we assume that x is a nonnegative real and then by √x we mean the nonnegative square root.  But for other numbers, such as negative real numbers and non-real complex numbers, there is no way to conistently choose one of the two square roots to be "the" square root.  That is, -i has just as much a claim to be "the square root" of -1 as i does, and -i√2 has just as much a claim to be "the" square root of -2 as i√2 does.

It is, of course, possible to make a more or less arbitrary choice of one particular square root of each complex number to define a single-valued "square root function".  In complex analysis this is called a *branch* of the multi-valued square root function.  But any such function will necessarily (A) be discontinuous somewhere (its "branch cut") and (B) fail to satisfy the law √a√b = √(ab) in some cases.  The most common branch of the square root takes the square root of a nonreal complex number to have the same sign of its imaginary part, and the square root of a negative real number to have positive imaginary part, thus giving i for -1 and i√2 for -2; this is sometimes called the "principal" square root.  This is discontinuous on the negative reals, as √(-1-0.000001i) will be close to i while √(1+0.000001i) will be close to -i.  It also fails the law √a√b = √(ab), e.g. √(-1)√(-1) = i*i = -1 while √((-1)(-1)) = √1 = 1.

It appears that gnome-calculator has chosen a different branch of the square root where the square root of the negative of a *perfect square integer* has positive imaginary part (that is, √(-1) = i, √(-4) = 2i, and so on) while the square root of any *other* negative real number has negative imaginary part (that is, √(-2) = -i√2, √(-3) = -i√3, and so on).  Mathematically it's not clear that this is any worse than the usual "principal" square root, although it certainly seems likely to be more surprising.  However, if it prompts more people to reflect on the meaning of √, that might be a good thing.  Even better would be to refuse to answer a question like sqrt(-2), or give a multivalued answer like ±i√2.  Indeed, the reason I found this issue is that my son was trying to answer a question about the domain and values of a function like √(x+7)/√(x-5), and was led to an incorrect conclusion by the fact that gnome-calculator makes an arbitrary choice for a square root of a negative number, rather than being honest about its multivaluedness.

Pressing/Holding the "backspace" key in Gnome Calculator 46 Text Input Field Causes Wireplumber High CPU Usage and Writes to Disk
Pressing/Holding the "backspace" key in Gnome Calculator 46 Text Input Field Causes Wireplumber High CPU Usage and Writes to Disk

note.body: Thanks for reporting this issue, however I am sure this should not be a GNOME Calculator issue, however I can't tell which project this should be moved to. The Alert sound settings is inside the GNOME Control Center = Settings project, but the sound feedback from the text component (gtksourceview in this case), when trying to delete from an empty input field seems to be coming from event sounds/input feedback sounds functionality of GTK (if not, GTK folks please reassign to the correct project and excuse me).

target_title: Pressing/Holding the "backspace" key in Gnome Calculator 46 Text Input Field Causes Wireplumber High CPU Usage and Writes to Disk

note.body:
It seems the "alert" sound is triggering this issue. Disabling the alert sound (Gnome Settings: Sound: Sounds: Alert Sound: None) stops the high CPU usage and writes to disk. There is something fishy going on with Wireplumber and the Gnome system alert sound playback. System sounds should not consume large amounts of CPU resources and make MiB writes to disk. The alert sound should be cached in memory after being read from disk and then played back from there on repeated keystrokes. Wireplumber shouldn't need to write anything to disk to play the sound. This is all very odd to see.

![alert_sound_to_none_1](/uploads/fe73ca1b9e07e5e59054eccf1e862186/alert_sound_to_none_1.png)
![alert_sound_to_none_2](/uploads/a83c67bdc1ab9d00d3da649755bfddb9/alert_sound_to_none_2.png)

target_title: Pressing/Holding the "backspace" key in Gnome Calculator 46 Text Input Field Causes Wireplumber High CPU Usage and Writes to Disk

note.body:
Here's a screen cast of the issue in action ~~(it looks like "gjs" is doing some of the writes to disk?)~~ (just tested again, and gjs is not the issue, those writes were for the screencast):

![wireplumber_high_cpu_useage](/uploads/b7b5e0d1bf1551df83a31d5d6ca21b39/wireplumber_high_cpu_useage.mp4)

Feel free to reopen if it still happens for you, and if it does, please try to provide a backtrace (see https://blogs.gnome.org/mcatanzaro/2021/09/18/creating-quality-backtraces-for-crash-reports/ for details).

Test failed on RISC-V devices. `Number test` needs 75s.

note.body: Reverted the iterations bump. Not entirely sure whether that's the right thing to do, but the failure mentioned in !177 does not seem to happen anymore (at least locally for me - tried calculator manually with the 176 and 432, which was causing the failure for the developer doing the MR, probably that is why he increased the iterations to 500, to make sure the  "and 432" gets automatically tested - so all numbers between 1 and 500 are AND-ed with all numbers between 1 and 500.), and I don't see the reason of keeping that if it breaks other resources and increases tests runtime.

target_title: Test failed on RISC-V devices. `Number test` needs 75s.
Test failed on RISC-V devices. `Number test` needs 75s.

note.body:
A git bisect riscv64 found the commit https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calculator/-/commit/1d54045767c39f468ac5a8bf70bdec0913d60903?merge_request_iid=177. It increased the number of iterations in `test_and` from 1k to 250k. 

This is also noticeable on x86_64 but not to a point where it causes a test failure. On my desktop (i7-12700) the numbers went from

```
1/6 Serializer test          OK              0.01s
2/6 Currency test            OK              0.01s
3/6 gcalc-parsing            OK              0.01s
4/6 gcalc-solve-basic        OK              0.01s
5/6 Number test              OK              0.04s
6/6 Equation test            OK              0.39s
```

to

```
1/6 Currency test            OK              0.03s
2/6 Serializer test          OK              0.02s
3/6 gcalc-parsing            OK              0.02s
4/6 gcalc-solve-basic        OK              0.02s
5/6 Equation test            OK              0.50s
6/6 Number test              OK              9.07s
```

So the question is if that many iterations are needed or if the timeout should be bumped.

target_title: history-entry: Apply `dim-label` CSS class
Experiment with alternate UI and custom widget styling

note.body:
I kind of like it actually, as a matter of principle that buttons do look more like buttons in light mode, reminiscent of their physical counterparts, and indicating that they are interactive.

The shadows are maybe not enough alone to compensate the sea of white that is the background in light mode, with the tight spacing. If you want to make the keys stand out more, you could try having the background (i.e. the slate of the calculator) be some sort of mid-gray (not dark enough that black shadows are ineffective, but at least not white). I'd be really curious to see how it would look; I think that's the only missing aspect that could make this a no-regression UX compared to the current "white background, darker keys" approach.

Dark mode is a trickier thing, however; there, your changes are nearly imperceptible because the black shadows are nearly invisible atop a dark-gray background, and short of having a lighter slate background than nearly-pure-black (i.e. like a physical mid-gray calculator in dimly lit situations, instead) I don't know that the shadows would make sense in dark mode.

note.body: I didn't make it confidential (at least not on purpose). I assumed it was some kind of spam protection. Thank you for making it public.

target_title: Unit conversion in the input field

note.body: This ticket is marked as confidential, so way less people can look at (or work on) this ticket. By not making an issue public without a good reason, you diminish chances that someone can look at this. Confidentiality usually refers to security vulnerabilities, so I am making this ticket public.
